description: "A magician fox?", Khohai asked while he nibbled on his fishbones. "Oh yea, i heard of those oddballs. Weird foxes, trying to be something better." "You don´t understand, old mite", Never replied. "I´m not talking about these harmless idiots - that fox was a real magician...he did unbelievable things, i´ve seen it. And his fur is white!" Now, Khohai looked up. "Dear - did ya eat an ill rat again, eh? Been a long time since i heard such nonsense! There are red foxes, black foxes, even hybrids of the two - but no white ones. There never were. Not of our kind, at least. Even our old stories doesn´t have any and i guess i don´t have to mention how colorful some critters are in there." "I´m telling you the truth!", the young vixen insisted. "Amusing." Never stopped and sulked. She was surprised about her own disappointment. That old mite didn´t believe her. The dog fox grinned. "Ya cute when ya talking nonsense. Should do that more often. Fish?." Never wrinkled her nose. "And you are disgusting, as always. No thanks." Never, having a conversation with Khohai, an old Todd she is befriended with. (though she would never admit that in her pride.) Someone's eavesdropping their conversation....can you see who?

description: I may put this in the scraps section later. Comp for my final rendering project. We have to draw a portrait of a mythological creature and incorperate a bunch of imagerey into it, preferably with some sort of theme. I chose ceberus as my creature, and being that he's the guardian of the underworld, I picked a bunch of death/underworld imagery for the theme. Much referencing of Dore's etchings of Dante's Divine Comedy to get ideas. The final will be done on black scratchboard with stippling. It may kill me. Edit: Two questions that appeared frequently in the comments which I wanted to address: 1-The piece was done in mechanical pencil on two layers of tracing paper. The bottom layer had the initial line drawing, the top had tone. I just scanned them both in on top of eachother. 2-I'm thoroughly astounded/pleased at the reaction this piece has received. I never expected to see it on the front page! So, I'm going to leave it in my main gallery instead of putting it in scraps, even after I upload the final. Thank you all for the postive feedback! I'm happy to say my teacher was pleased with it as well. Edit2: I have received a LOT of requests from people to use this image as a tattoo. I appreciate the interest but due to the number of requests I've received I'm afraid I can't just hand out the rights to this image left and right. I'm in negotiations with a tattoo artist to purchase a license of this image for one-time use. If you are interested in using this image for a tattoo, please email me and we can discuss a licensing fee. Edit3: Thank you guys for the continued support and feedback! Just to let you new watchers/commenters know, I actually don't update this gallery anymore. You can find new art over here:

description: A vision of nature in the context of quantum patterns creating the whole from the microscopic to the macroscopic. Some proposed keys to understanding...: A pattern is the form that composes or generates each part, and each to the rest of the whole. A fractal is a pattern that repeats at ever increasing and/or decreasing scale, that can be subdivided in parts, each of which is a smaller copy of the whole. A hologram is a 2D plane that generates a 3D space when it is illuminated in the right manner. Each part of the hologram contains the image of the whole, even if it is torn into pieces. Relativity is the perceptive theory that parts (i.e. space and time) are not in fact separate from the whole, but one continuum (spacetime). Despite the apparent separateness of things at the explicate level, everything is a seamless extension of everything else into an infinitely ornate magic carpet. To scope is to examine or investigate the range of one's perceptions, thoughts, or actions. A fugue is a musical composition (and/or texture) in which a theme(s) is echoed successively through a multitude of differing voices forming a symphonic tapestry. The psychic-genome concept, meaning genetic information of the mind, construes that organisms DNA is intimately linked with the corresponding mind in ways that manifest in its habitual patterns of activity. Epistemology, the nature of knowing, calls into question the parabolic relationship of knower, that which is known, and unknown. THY KINGDOM COME [link] 24x36 acrylic on canvas detail: [link]

description: EDIT : Higher scan resolution for a better quality ! Another dragon for my book project. From Dust, the Legend reborn. De la Poussière renaît la Légende... COMMENTS PLEASE !! Medium : Coffee/Pigments/Pencil FAQ : What is O Ka-Fée ? O Ka-Fée is the term concerning all my paintings done with coffee. It concerns the way of painting and of obtaining textures with coffee. It's about projections of coffee, which once in stains on the sheet, undergo injections of pigments. (Powder, colorex, watercolor.) Textures realized by coffee by drying (more or less sweetened) are unique, they are more interesting than those realized with water. The coffee is a rather complex medium has to master, it's necessary to know its reactions to be able to manipulate it with pigments, we learn it every day. O Ka-Fée also concern my graphic style and the whole universe which gets free of it. It's for that the term is protected by copyright. Please, respect my universe and work. / Version FR FAQ : Qu'est ce que O Ka-Fée ? O Ka-Fée est le terme concernant mes peintures réalisées avec pour base de café. Il s'agit de la manière de peindre et d'obtenir des textures réalisées par le café. Dans un premier temps ce sont des projections de café dans lesquelles ensuite on injecte des pigments. (Poudres, colorex, aquarelle.) Les textures réalisées par le café (plus ou moins sucré et selon la marque.) sont uniques, elles sont plus fortes et intéressantes que celles réalisées avec l'eau. Le café est un médium complexe a maitriser, il est important de connaître ses réactions afin de les manipuler avec les pigments, on en apprend tous les jours de part ce médium. O Ka-Fée concerne aussi mon univers et style graphique, ce sont souvent des peintures et univers libres, avec du mouvement et de la poésie. Merci de respecter mon travail et univers. - More O Ka-Fée art :

description: WTF you ask? Well basically the US and Canadian government is full of greedy bastards who decided that it would be a great idea to let wealthy trophy hunters to hunt down polar bears if they pay a large thumb of money for a license. And of course how can anyone possibly live in this world without a polar bear head hanging on the wall? Better shoot one before they go extinct from the melting ice caps right? Because then there'll be just a boring deer head on the wall instead and how can anyone live with that? You're not a real man until you have enough muscle strength in you finger to pull a trigger because that's what defines manliness, without a doubt! I'm just full of bitter sarcasm right now. If you're not a "real man" and believe polar bears shouldn't be become stuffed heads on the walls, then you can help by donating to [link] They are currently working on suing the government and they need your help to make it happen. (And yes, this is all true and not some scam, check out the link and confirm it yourself. The Defenders of Wildlife is a trustworthy organization that has existed for decades. They're like the ASPCA for wildlife.) No money? Then sign a petition, it's easy and free [link] your name and info will be kept a secrete so don't worry about that. This drawing was sold to and the profit was donated to help these animals Every now and then I will be doing some water colors of endangered wildlife titled "Let There Be Life: (name of animal) " to promote awareness and raise funds. I used this beautiful photograph for reference [link] I don't know the original photographer so sorry I can't give more credit.

description: In Egyptian Mythology, Isis was supposed to marry the god Set, but instead wed his brother Osiris. In jealousy, Set killed Osiris and hid his body in the Nile. Isis recovered Osiris' corpse and prepared him properly for burial but at the funeral, Set stole the body, hacked it into pieces and scattered the pieces across the earth. Her devotion being so strong, Isis recovered the pieces of the body and reconstructed the fallen god Osiris. In her grief, Isis transformed into a bird and circled in the air, crying out her sorrow and deep lament. The wind she made with her wings wafted over her husband and new life came into him and he was reborn. To me, this story talks about the way we can become fragmented - our lives are cut up and compartmentalized- and we become role players, filling various parts but never feeling whole. We need to breathe. We need to allow our souls to return to our bodies, and -in prayer or meditation, or in simply being still and quiet- we can rejoin our fragmented selves and become entire once again. --- 24" x 36" Mixed Media on Canvas 2007

description: After my epic fail at realistic painting, I decided to cool off and do something experimental for fun. I am sure this is inspired by one of my very favorite DA artists whose beautiful, antique looking illustrative work is just.... some of the best on the site. And some of my favorite, period. Usually, I am extremely allergic to warm colors, and so I resolved to start with a very warm, very dark wash and see where it went from there. With somewhat surprising results. I like some parts better than others, but on the whole (considering I hadn't the slightest idea of what I was doing) it turned out fairly well. I'm still waffling on the border. Leaving it alone makes the image much more open, and somewhat unfinished. I considered going over it with a dark green wash, which would close in the picture and pop the red forward like crazy. Or to just mat it with the image alone, and don't do a thing with the border, as it would be covered up.

description: First of all: This guy is up for auction on ebay! Check it out! [link] Though it doesn't say so on the ebay listing, I will ship worldwide; the cost for shipping would just be a bit more. :} This is an image that's been over a year in the making.. sort of. In july-august of 2011 I tried to do an oil painting of a white horse head for my sister...tried and tried and tried and nearly sent myself to hospital from lack of sleep/eating/drinking etc. etc. I hallucinated that daleks were living in various shapes and colors and that river song and the doctor were having an argument about how the eye was painted. Yeah. It was that bad. I eventually gave up, but I'm the most stubborn mule you'll ever meet, so I thought "hey, I'll just use a different picture of the same theme".. another horse head...a different medium. I got permission from to use this photo [link] and I tried to paint it digitally. Tried and tried and tried... still failed... a couple months ago I tried again, same photo, but with colored pencils, a lot of turpenoid, and some smooth watercolor paper...yeah, failed that one too. So, about a week ago, I dug my heels in and decided to try one more time. I'm supposed to be taking a break from art, but for whatever reason I just really needed to prove to myself that I COULD still draw... I DID still have it in me, somewhere, to remember how to create... so, yeah. Here we go. Just black colored pencils on some vellum bristol paper. It's not perfect, and I didn't get every detail correct... but I think that's okay. I finished it, it's done, I won. Hah! Many thanks to for letting me drool all over and use her gorgeous photos. :} (oh, and some of the weird little blobs in the black background aren't really there.. that's a scanner thing. )

description: With this series of work, I continued my work with mermaids and sea creatures, but focused particularly on the octopus. An octopus' shape is fascinating, and I wanted to explore the juxtaposition of the flow of the mermaids hair and curl of the octopustentacles. I love drawing womens faces, and strive toward infusing them with strength, beauty, and a bit of mystery. This series of work was done on wooden panels with graphite pencil, acrylic paint and glazing medium, and ink pens. 16" x 16"

description: In Norse mythology, Yggdrasil is the World Tree, a great ash tree located at the center of the universe and joining the nine worlds of Norse cosmology. The trunk of the tree may be thought of as forming a vertical axis around which these worlds are situated, with ?sgard, realm of the gods, at the top and the Hel, located in Niflheim, at the bottom. Midgard, our world that is inhabited by humans, is located in the middle and surrounded by Jötunheim, land of Jötunn, both of which are separated by the ocean. According to Atiteco myth, The existence of the Flowering Mountain Earth precedes that of the world as it is known today. Before there was a world, a lone tree stood in the center of all that existed. As the creation of the world approached, the tree was impregnated and its branches grew a single fruit of each thing known to humankind. In addition to physical objects such as rocks, it grew lightening and even segments of time. As the tree bore more and more fruit, it was no longer able to support everything which grew upon it, and so the fruit fell, smashing open upon the ground and scattering seeds about. These seeds took root and grew, nurtured by the original tree and protected beneath its canopy, eventually crowding out the Father/Mother (Ti Tie Ti Tixel). The Tree of Life, or Etz haChayim ( ?? ????? ) in Hebrew, is a mystical symbol within the Kabbalah of esoteric Judaism used to describe the path to God and the manner in which He created the world ex nihilo (out of nothing). The Kabbalists developed this concept into a full model of reality, using the tree to depict a "map" of creation. The tree of life has been called the "cosmology" of the Kabbalah. In kabbalah, Etz Chaim is a mystical symbol used to understand the nature of God and the manner in which He created the world. ~~~~~~~~ Kundalini (ku??alin? is ????????? in Sanskrit), literally "coiled". In Indian yoga, a "corporeal energy" - an unconscious, instinctive or libidinal force or Shakti - envisioned either as a goddess or else as a sleeping serpent coiled at the base of the spine, hence a number of English renderings of the term such as 'serpent power'. Kundalini is considered a part of the subtle body along with chakras (energy centres) and nadis (channels). The overall conception has many points in common with Chinese acupuncture. Yoga and Tantra propose that this energy may be "awoken" by such means as austerities, breath and other physical exercises, visualization and chanting. It may then rise up a subtle channel at the spine (called Sushumna) to the head, bringing psychological illumination. Each chakra is said to contain special characteristics. Yogis tend to attempt this alone, Tantrics in couples, both usually under the instruction of a guru. When Kundalini Shakti is conceived as a goddess then, when it rises to the head it unites itself with the Supreme Being (Lord Shiva). The aspirant gets engrossed in deep meditation and infinite bliss.

description: Oils on panel 14 x 12" 1999 My favorite author. There is no color photo of this. My reference is a B & W photo on the back of the book "The Early Ayn Rand". It's a photo of her as she looked just having arrived in the United States from the Soviet Union (she was born in Russia), never to return, as she loved the United States passionately even before she got the hell out of the Soviet Union. Drab dress with a little tear, the kind of dress her hear-to-for wealthy family was reduced to after the Soviets destroyed Russia, nationalizing her father's pharmacy. I imagined all the color, and that surely she would have found a way to put some color, a flower or something in that torn dress. I don't imagine anyone would care about this painting unless they know her story. The greatest author and philosopher in history. Not a pretty woman, but she made a point of making herself attractive as she could during her great life. By the way her book "Atlas Shrugged" is the "second most influential book for Americans today" after the Bible, according to a joint survey conducted by the Library of Congress and the Book of the Month Club. My portrait is featured in the new book The Selfish Path to Romance. [link]

description: Subject matter and title notwithstanding, this painting actually has nothing whatever to do with Halloween, or goth-ness in general. (But I figured October was a good time to paint it nevertheless.) Rather, Grim is the name of the raven; he is a character from the saga I’m writing, the very first character I’ve painted. (‘Grim’ was a common personal name in medieval Scandinavia, meaning ‘mask’.) Here is the super-condensed story of Grim (so far): Up until he entered the saga, the life of Grim (then a man) was quite uneventful. Then along came a man who tried to feed him to a wolf. Grim had dreamt about this man beforehand, and when the man realized this, and realized that he needed Grim’s help, he gave himself to the wolf instead (this man can’t die, which comes in handy now and then). Along went Grim with this man, whose name was Kauras, north to Permia, where they found a giant who owned a magical horse, descendant, it was said, from Sleipnir himself. It was this horse Kauras wanted, and after a few cunning adventures he and Grim managed to defeat the giant. In doing so, however, Grim was mortally wounded. On their way north the two men had encountered an old women who understood what would happen to Grim; she had given Kauras a small piece of ivory, which she told him to put under Grim’s tongue when he most needed it. Kneeling over Grim as he was dying, Kauras understood this was the time the woman meant; he put the ivory under Grim’s tongue and instantly he turned into a raven—a raven with a white tongue. Thus Grim survived a trip he thought he would not, and although his shape was now different, his mind was still that of a man. He returned with Kauras from Permia and has been aiding him ever since.I'm going to try to paint at least one character from the saga per month from now on, gradually working my way up to humans (for which I need more practice). Next I shall attempt Jarngeir (in horse-form), the giant who (almost) killed Grim. I’m not all that happy with the way the spattering turned out. I think a spatter could have worked, but apparently I need to practice my spattering like I need to practice everything else. Ah well. Tomorrow is another piece of paper. Watercolor, 16” x 20”, 2013.

description: A Celtic goddess from the Welsh Mabinogion, Arianrhod is the keeper of the Silver Wheel of stars, symbol of time, kama and reincarnation. She is a mother aspect of the ancient triple Goddess, and is also associated with beauty and fertility. I designed the knotwork myself based on a twelve point circular grid - to represent the turning of the twelve months of the year. The continuous knot also represents the flow of life, ever interweaving and changing form in an eternal pattern. Painted for 's Celtic myths and legends contest 8.5in x 8.5in watercolour

description: I could almost swear that watercolors can sense fear...because whenever I'm afraid to try out a new color scheme things get out of hand. It's also sort of discouraging when you find out that the paper you THOUGHT was professional grade watercolor paper is actually crappy paper that doesn't absorb the pigment right, and ends up spreading all over the sheet like mad. I'm in the process of trying out different papers and it is proving to be frustrating. I know it's a learning process, but I can't help but get upset when the paint doesn't cooperate like I want it too. Thank you for appreciating my are nonetheless. Original painting is for sale, please note me if you are interested. Watercolors on Strathmore cold press paper.

description: The Black Fox Je L'yuvoczack Bruvok This is a large piece and the original is staying with me. It's a deeply personal piece, as the melanistic red fox (also known as the black fox, the silver fox, and the gray fox) is a long-time, personal guide of mine. I decided to go with a very dark colour scheme, and also indicate my connection to cool blues, as well as the wind. * Limited edition prints will eventually be made available, but for now, photo quality (instead of giclee) prints are possible. * 38 x 51cm / 15 x 20 in Crescent illustrator's board, technical pens, pencil and aquarelle, metallic paint.

description: The shoes of the Doctor and Rose Tyler. Technically this is could be considered Doctor Who fanart. However, since it did not show the portraits of either figure, I thought it didn't necissarily have to be categorized as fanart. This was done for juliet418 for Christmas. Title: True Love is Timeless Medium: Acrylic on canvas board Size: Approx. 11 x 14 inches There's also a song that goes with it titled, 'Ghost of a Rose' by Blackmore's Night. Here are the lyrics that were written on the back: she met her true love there, and she told him. She would say: ' Promise me, when you see a white rose youll think of me, I love you so, never let go. I will be your ghost of a rose.' Her eyes believed in mysteries. ****** Her spirit wild, heart of a child, yet gentle still, and quiet and mild, and he loved her, when she would say: ' Promise me, when you see, a white rose youll think of me, I love you so, never let go. I will be your ghost of a rose.' When all was done, she turned to run, dancing right into the setting sun as he watched her. And evermore, he thought he saw, a glimpse of her upon the rose forever, he hear her say: ' Promise me when you see a white rose youll think of me, I love you so, never let go. I will be your ghost of a rose.' Ghost of a rose ***************** This song is just perfect for the Doctor and Rose.

A little bit about the world. Here, once upon a time, lived a great civilization of living creature, the cult of which was art and architecture. No one knows when they lived here and when gone. After the disappearance, they left a lot of ruins, arches and bridges ... They lived among the magnificent landscapes, they were surrounded by endless waterfalls and ravines, mountains and plains. Creatures skillfully linked these places each other by means gorgeous architecture. Sometimes, casual visitors from other worlds wander through these places (as here ), but no one has yet dared to live here. Abandoned man-made architecture is closely intertwined with nature, as if it has always been, at all times and forever ..

description: For if one is to drink much from a bottle labeled poison, its almost certain to disagree with one sooner or later This is an idea I had been working with *in my head* for quiet a while I originally wanted some Camille rose Garcia- inspired girl holding a baking tray with munted edible creations upon it So I think I might create that one later But this is what I came out with at the time! I also tried for something a little different *coloring wise* ****I KNOW THIS IS REALLY PINK****  and painted most of this image up! I use watercolor pencils but normally dont add much waterso this time I decided to go a bit freer with coloursand have a play! I also love using white out and white paint to add in some extra effect. This whole image has been one of my *lots of different bits and pieces artworks* .. Everything I draw is on A3 paper and almost everything in this image was separate images all put together as one whole at the end! The border, the knife rack, the girl, the weirdo poodle thing, the background, the scrolls, the diamondsall drawn separately. I just try plan it all in my head and how I wish it to look and then draw pieces up at a time scan them in and position them I just find I cant restrict myself to the A3 paper when drawing up these kind of ideas. I drew the scroll with the words on it lastand I was worried I wouldnt have it fit in very nice and its now my favorite aspect of this drawing for some reason -shrugs- Im happy with it. I used more patters that I bought from craft shops in order to do the nice wallpaper and dress patterns I painted the white/pink round border. I have to say that everything really did turn out better than I expected it to The scroll saying is from the Alice in wonderland movie- I was watching it while I drew *it helps inspire* and I thought the saying was rather fitting for the image Its been a while since I drew an image with some kind of fun freaky animal Its almost tiring to draw cartoony spacked out animals for me since I think thats all I use to do for years as a kid! And now its kinda a chore But at least I find it simple and almost boringly easy to do AND it makes the image a bit more interesting OH I FORGOT TO MENTION...she has coke in her right pinky fingernail alittle pile of powder!! Anyway I hope you enjoy. Just a bit of fun. -tegan Coddington Full view if youre interested.

description: This image is about my passion for my art. I live and breathe to create because it is what makes me happy. It disgusts a lot of people to see art getting stolen When you slave for hours on end  And pump so much love into your pieces For someone to simply take it- try and claim it They will never understand the love, or even the story behind the image. ---- AS for people telling artists how to react when there art gets stolen -go put your 2cents someplace else- its up to the artist how he/she feels about seeing there work preproduced and having the true artist shat on. -shrugs- stop your wining and deal with your own issues. ----- This took me a while to complete The drawing is a full A3 size  like all of my drawings- I coloured it with Faber castel watercolour pencils  I dont usually add water but I did this time. I used metallic pens for the details like the netting on her face and her jewellery, but the it did not turn out in the scan. the little squid wallpaper designs around the border were also made by me! its so fun to do! Enjoy available to WEAR on t-shirts
